stem: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset, severe chest pain radiating to his left arm. He is diaphoretic and reports feeling short of breath. Which of the following actions are MOST appropriate at this time? Select ALL that apply.

patient.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset, severe chest pain radiating to left arm, shortness of breath

itemContext.sbar: Patient is a 62-year-old male presenting with acute chest pain, radiating to left arm. Diaphoretic and SOB. Rule out MI.

rationale.correct: Administer oxygen to improve oxygen saturation and reduce myocardial ischemia. Obtain a 12-lead EKG to assess for ST-segment elevation or other signs of myocardial infarction. Establish IV access for medication administration and fluid resuscitation. Administer aspirin to inhibit platelet aggregation and reduce thrombus formation.
rationale.incorrect: Administer a beta-blocker (metoprolol) can worsen hypotension in the acute setting of a potential MI. Order a psychiatric consult is not the priority in the acute setting of a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of an MI.
clinicalPearls: Time is muscle - rapid assessment and intervention are crucial in patients with suspected MI.
Always rule out life-threatening causes of chest pain first.
Be cautious when administering nitroglycerin to patients with hypotension.
Atypical presentations of MI are more common in women, elderly, and patients with diabetes.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing on a single symptom instead of the overall clinical picture and prioritizing interventions that are not immediately life-saving.
questionTrap.tip: Prioritize interventions that address the ABCs (airway, breathing, circulation) and stabilize the patient.

mnemonic.name: MONA
mnemonic.description: Morphine, Oxygen, Nitroglycerin, Aspirin - remember the initial interventions for acute coronary syndrome (Note: Morphine use is decreasing; assess need for pain control).
mnemonic.caveat: Sequence and appropriateness depend on the patient's condition and contraindications (e.g., hypotension for nitroglycerin).
